caption_original:
Inuk leader, Sheila Watt-Cloutier, is an activist at the crossroads of Indigenous rights and environmental advocacy.
 
She was nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize Concert prize for her environmental and political activism, which highlighted the effects of climate change on Inuit communities. http://ow.ly/f9Y430fRo4V 
#WomensHistoryMonth
#IndigenousWomen

caption_original: “From the North” brings together musicians, visual artists, media artists, storytellers, dancers and Dene and Inuit athletes from the territories on a tour of the northern capital cities – Whitehorse, Yellowknife and Iqaluit – followed by stops in Ottawa, Montréal and Vancouver. Check out the schedule here: http://ow.ly/KENv30ge9FD

caption_original: Ukkusiksalik National Park in Nunavut is a traditional hunting and fishing ground for Inuit. Imagine their gatherings as you hike the trails or paddle the traditional routes Inuit men and women have traveled for centuries. http://ow.ly/A9oZ30g9IAx  #IndigenousLanguages

caption_original: The Canol Trail telephone wire clean-up is a joint project between the Government of Canada, the Government of the Northwest Territories, and the Doi T’oh Territorial Park Corporation. Over the last three years, telephone wire left over from the construction and operation of the Canadian Oil (CANOL) pipeline has been cut and removed from the trail. The contract for the next phase of the remediation project was recently awarded. To learn more about the Canol Trail Remediation Project visit: http://ow.ly/RRDl30fOiL1
caption_cleaned: The Canol Trail telephone wire clean-up is a joint project between the Government of Canada, the Government of the Northwest Territories, and the Doi T’oh Territorial Park Corporation. Over the last three years, telephone wire left over from the construction and operation of the Canadian Oil (CANOL) pipeline has been cut and removed from the trail. The contract for the next phase of the remediation project was recently awarded. To learn more about the Canol Trail Remediation Project visit: 1

caption_original:
Drone imagery was taken along the Canol Heritage Trail (NWT) to produce historical records before the remediation project begins. These records will be used to create base maps for community meetings, 3D digital models, and help to track progress as the project proceeds. The imagery will also be added to the region’s repository of satellite photos and to the archives at the Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre. 
To learn more about the Canol Trail Remediation Project, visit: http://ow.ly/FVXM30fC2fv

caption_original:
It's World Food Day!
In case you missed it, a few lucky Nunavut women found a berry picking "gold mine" last month in Northern Quebec! Elaine Metuq says the plants were "brimming with black crowberries in fist-sized clusters".

Tonight's 2017 Yellowknife Chamber of Commerce Business Award Gala will celebrate the outstanding contributions of the business community. Some of the categories include: Aboriginal Entrepreneurship Award, Trailblazers Women in Business Award, and Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award. Congratulations and good luck to all the nominees! For the full list visit: http://ow.ly/we4030g1AWE

caption_original: The first in a series of Mapping the Way video vignettes about Yukon First Nations land claims and self-government explores “Together Today for Our Children Tomorrow”, a document that was prepared by Yukon First Nations that initiated the land claim negotiation process over 40 years ago.
